dc:description:
The *PROM1* gene was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive retinal degeneration in 2000 (PMID: 10587575). Subsequent publications expanded the phenotypic spectrum associated with homozygous or compound heterozygous *PROM1* variants to include diverse diagnoses such as retinitis pigmentosa 41 (PMID: 17605048) and cone-rod dystrophy 12 (PMID: 24474277). These cases typically have onset in childhood or adolescence and exhibit a wide variety of retinal features ranging from macular degeneration, progressive reduction in visual acuity, and central scotoma to night blindness, peripheral visual field loss, retinal blood vessel attenuation, and optic disc pallor. Electroretinogram responses are generally decreased in amplitude or undetectable, particularly from cones. Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium in the macula is often observed and may be described as bullâ€™s eye maculopathy. Optical coherence tomography images generally show retinal thinning and particularly loss of the photoreceptor layer. The spectrum of disease also includes cases with heterozygous *PROM1* variants diagnosed as cone-rod dystrophy 12 (PMID: 35947379), Stargardt-like macular dystrophy (PMID: 29416601), or retinal macular dystrophy type 2 (PMID: 18654668). These heterozygous cases exhibit relatively later onset but a similar range of phenotypes that can include reduced visual acuity, bull's-eye macular dystrophy, progressive macular atrophy, color vision abnormalities, and night blindness. Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping & Splitting Working Group, recessive cases of cone-rod dystrophy or retinitis pigmentosa were compared with dominant cases of cone-rod dystrophy, retinal macular dystrophy, or Stargardt-like maculopathy. The shared mode of inheritance, molecular mechanism (biallelic loss-of-function) and phenotypic overlap among recessive cases motivated cone-rod dystrophy 12 and retinitis pigmentosa 41 to be combined into a single gene curation, with the lumped disease entity referred to as PROM1-related recessive retinopathy. On the other hand, cases with overlapping phenotypes but a dominant mode of inheritance differed in their molecular mechanism (dominant negative), whereas the recessive families had unaffected heterozygous carriers. Therefore, dominant cases have been lumped into a separate disease entity, referred to as PROM1-related dominant retinopathy.

Eight suspected disease-causing variants were scored as part of this curation (three nonsense, three frameshift, one canonical splice site variant, and one non-canonical intronic variant disrupting splicing), which have been collectively reported in six probands in six publications (PMID: 10587575, PMID: 17605048, PMID: 24474277, PMID: 24763286, PMID: 25472526, PMID: 26702251). Four of the probands scored in this curation harbored the variant in the homozygous state, with three reported as consanguineous, while two other probands harbored variants in compound heterozygosity. Two large families with evidence of co-segregation of the genotype with affected status contributed to the scoring of the gene-disease relationship (PMID: 10587575, PMID: 17605048). The literature included more case-level and co-segregation evidence, but its inclusion in this curation was not necessary to reach the maximum score for genetic evidence.

This gene-disease association is also supported by experimental evidence indicating that degeneration of the photoreceptor layer may be the shared defect underlying *PROM1*-related recessive disease. *PROM1* is specifically expressed in retinal tissues (PMID: 30239781) and the protein product localizes particularly to the discs at the base of the photoreceptor cell outer segments (PMID: 10587575, PMID: 18654668). This localization is consistent with the known association of PROM1 with membrane protrusions in general (PMID: 10681530) and its proposed function as an organizer of cell membrane topology in the morphogenesis of the developing photoreceptor cell outer segment disc membrane. The CDHR1 gene product similarly localizes to these structures, co-immunoprecipitates with PROM1 (PMID: 18654668), and harbors variants associated with cone-rod dystrophy 15 (PMID: 20805371), retinal macular dystrophy (PMID: 28765526), and retinitis pigmentosa 65 (PMID: 20087419). Homozygous knockout of the mouse ortholog *Prom1* results in light-dependent degeneration of the photoreceptor and outer nuclear layers, and defective dark-adapted electroretinogram responses (PMID: 25414197). Homozygous deletion of the zebrafish ortholog *Prom1b* results in photoreceptor degeneration, enhanced apoptosis, loss of the outer nuclear layer, and delayed morphogenesis of outer segment discs (PMID: 31362982).

In summary, *PROM1* is definitively associated with PROM1-related recessive retinopathy. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both research and diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time without the emergence of contradictory evidence, leading to a Definitive classification. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Retina Gene Curation Expert Panel on April 4th, 2024 (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description: Default scoring is considered appropriate, as the retinal expression of the PROM1 transcript is highly specific relative to the levels in other tissues.
The EyeIntegration v2.12 dataset shows that PROM1 is specifically expressed in the human retina, and to a lesser degree in other tissues such as the salivary gland.
evidence.rdfs:label: PROM1 is specifically expressed in human retina.

evidence.dc:description: The co-immunoprecipitation data are consistent with the matching localizations of PROM1 and CDHR1 to the base of the photoreceptor outer segments within the mouse retina, and the role of variants in both genes in causing cone-rod dystrophy, macular dystrophy, and retinitis pigmentosa cases.
PROM1 and CDHR1 both localize to the base of the photoreceptor outer segments (Fig. 3), and immunoprecipitation of either protein successfully co-immunoprecipitates the other (Fig. 4).
evidence.rdfs:label: PROM1 interacts with CDHR1.

evidence.dc:description: Similar evidence has already been scored from PMID: 18654668.

The localization of PROM1 to the outer segment discs in photoreceptor cells is consistent with its suspected role in protecting against the degeneration of the macula and other retinal structures composed of cone and rod photoreceptor cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: Prom1 localizes to the base of the rod outer segment.

evidence.dc:description: Default scoring is recommended since the role of PROM1 within these subcellular structures is consistent with its known association with membrane protrusions in general (PMID: 10681530) and proposed function as an organizer of cell membrane topology in the morphogenesis of the developing photoreceptor cell outer segment disc membrane.

The localization of PROM1 to the outer segment discs in photoreceptor cells is consistent with its suspected role in protecting against the degeneration of the macula and other retinal structures composed of cone and rod photoreceptor cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: PROM1 localizes to photoreceptor cell outer segment discs.

evidence.dc:description: The mouse model shows photoreceptor layer cell death, with similar results found in two mouse models (on different backgrounds). Reduced scoring is recommended since the article has assessed rod function but not cone function. The presence of the model on multiple genetic backgrounds has also been taken into account.

The degeneration of the outer cell retinal layers in the homozygous knockout mice (Figure 1) is consistent with the suspected role of Prom1 in protecting against the degeneration of the macula and other retinal structures composed of cone and rod photoreceptor cells. Photoreceptor and outer nuclear layer areas are completely lost by 20 days after birth (in the more severely affected strain). Microscopically, the mouse outer segment shows disordered photoreceptor cells and mislocalization of opsin proteins (Figure 2). The degeneration is light-dependent, so that dark conditions protect the photoreceptors from degeneration (Figure 3). Dark-adapted ERG was defective if mice were exposed to light (Figure 4).
evidence.rdfs:label: The Prom1 knockout mouse shows photoreceptor degeneration.

evidence.dc:description: The recessive mode of inheritance and phenotype of the model animals at the microscopic level match the outer segment defects of the human patients. Other human phenotypes such as ERG responses from photoreceptor cells were not assessed in the animal model.

The model shows loss of the outer nuclear layer specifically, accompanied by enhanced staining of TUNEL-positive cells (Figure 2), indicating a retinal degeneration phenotype. The retinal tissues show aberrant expression of phototransduction cascade components Gnb3, Gnat2, Gnb1, and Gnat1 (Figure 3). Delayed morphogenesis / fewer discs within the outer segment was also observed (Figure 6), with evidence of shedding outer segments (Figure 7) with Prph2 mislocalization (Figure 8).
evidence.rdfs:label: Prom1b knockout zebrafish shows photoreceptor degeneration.

evidence.dc:description: The family was genotyped by linkage analysis followed by sequencing of the candidate gene PROM1.
evidence.rdfs:label: Zhang_2007_Family

member.rdfs:label: Zhang_2007_Family_61037_Proband
member.detectionMethod: Genotyping consisted of linkage analysis within the family, mapping the causal variant to a particular region of chromosome 4p, followed by restriction digest analysis and Sanger sequencing of PCR products from the candidate gene PROM1.
member.previousTestingDescription: Previous testing consisted of linkage analysis within the family, mapping the causal variant to a region located approximately at chromosome 4p15.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The family has a diagnosis of severe retinitis pigmentosa, with features including Severely reduced visual acuity, Childhood onset, Macular degeneration advancing with age, Choriocapillaris atrophy, Retinal pigment epithelial atrophy, and Undetectable electroretinogram.

evidence.dc:description: The family was genotyped by linkage analysis followed by sequencing of the candidate gene PROM1.
evidence.rdfs:label: Maw_2000_Family_166

member.rdfs:label: Maw_2000_Family_166_Proband_IV-1
member.detectionMethod: The proband and her family members were initially genotyped by linkage analysis within the family, mapping the causal variant to a particular region of chromosome 4p, followed by Sanger sequencing of PCR products from the candidate PROM1 gene.
member.phenotypeFreeText: The proband and affected family members exhibit Retinal degeneration, Nyctalopia, Peripheral visual field loss, Childhood onset, Progressive visual loss, Undetectable electroretinogram, Attenuation of retinal blood vessels, Optic disc pallor, Pigmentary retinopathy, and Macular degeneration. One affected sibling also had polydactyly on one foot. Other features of Bardet-Biedl syndrome were not present. One parent had retinal degeneration in one eye and poor vision starting in the 5th decade of life.
member.previousTestingDescription: Previous testing consisted of linkage analysis within the family, mapping the causal variant to a particular region of chromosome 4p.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Shared phenotypes are Retinal degeneration, Nyctalopia, Peripheral visual field loss, Childhood onset, Progressive visual loss, Undetectable electroretinogram, Attenuation of retinal blood vessels, Optic disc pallor, Pigmentary retinopathy, and Macular degeneration. One affected individual also had polydactyly on one foot. Other features of Bardet-Biedl syndrome were not present. One parent had retinal degeneration in one eye and poor vision starting in the 5th decade of life.

evidence.rdfs:label: Eidinger_2015_Family_TB126_Proband_II-1
evidence.detectionMethod: Genotyping was performed homozygosity mapping within two affected family members, identifying several shared homozygous intervals that included PROM1 as the only known candidate locus, followed by Sanger sequencing of the PROM1 exons and intronic flanking sequences.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The proband reported onset of visual defects at age 7 years and was diagnosed with cone-rod dystrophy at age 9 years, with Moderately reduced visual acuity, Central scotoma, Decreased light- and dark-adapted electroretinogram amplitude, Retinal atrophy, Bull's eye maculopathy, Retinal thinning, Retinal pigment epithelial atrophy, Photoreceptor layer loss on macular OCT, Nyctalopia, Color vision defect, and Abnormality of pattern visual evoked potentials. Initially, cone ERG responses were more reduced while rod ERG was normal.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Previous testing consisted of homozygosity mapping within two affected family members, identifying several shared homozygous intervals that included PROM1 as the only known candidate locus.

evidence.dc:description: The variant has been up-scored for the in vitro splicing assay demonstrating that the variant leads to complete exon 22 skipping, consistent with the SpliceAI prediction of splice disruption (0.89 for splice acceptor loss and 0.86 for splice donor loss, predicted to result in skipping of exon 23, referred to as exon 22 in the paper since the first exon is non-coding). The exon is 93-bp long, so its skipping would be predicted to preserve frame. The variant has also been down-scored for the known consanguinity of the proband's parents.

evidence.rdfs:label: Beryozkin_2014_Family_MOL0256_Proband_II:2
evidence.detectionMethod: Genotpying consisted of homozygosity mapping in the three affected family members to identify shared regions of homozygosity between all three individuals, followed by Sanger sequencing of candidate genes from the homozygous regions; ABCA4, CEP290, CERKL, CRB1, CREB3, DHDDS, EYS, FAM161A, GUCY2D, IMPG2, LCA5, MFRP, NR2E3, NRL, RDH12, TULP1, and USH2A.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The proband has a diagnosis of cone rod dystrophy, with Very low visual acuity, Nystagmus, and High myopia.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Previous testing consisted of homozygosity mapping in the three affected family members to identify shared regions of homozygosity between all three individuals.

evidence.dc:description: NM_006017.3(PROM1):c.1157T>A (p.Leu386Ter) is a nonsense variant in exon 12 / 28 and is predicted to trigger nonsense mediated decay. Down-scoring has been recommended due to its presence in the homozygous state.

evidence.rdfs:label: Zhao_2015_Proband_Rp116
evidence.detectionMethod: Genotyping was performed by next-generation sequencing targeted to 186 known retinal disease genes, followed by Sanger sequencing-based confirmation. Segregation is implied to have been analyzed among the family members of the proband.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The proband has a diagnosis of retinitis pigmentosa, and is part of a cohort that was diagnosed based on typical fundal features, visual field constriction, and attenuated / abolished ERG.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Previous testing consisted of next-generation sequencing targeted to 186 known retinal disease genes.

evidence.dc:description: Default scoring is recommended since the NM_006017.3(PROM1):c.622del (p.Thr208LeufsTer23) variant triggers a frameshift in exon 6 of 28 and is predicted to trigger nonsense-mediated decay.
Default scoring is recommended since the NM_006017.3(PROM1):c.1355_1356insT (p.Tyr453LeufsTer12) variant triggers a frameshift in exon 13 of 28 and is predicted to trigger nonsense-mediated decay.
The variant has been down-scored due to the known consanguinity within the proband's family.

Despite the expectation of nonsense-mediated decay or severe dysfunction of the gene product, downscoring has been performed for the polydactyly phenotype of one family member, the possibility of a non-genotyped second gene contributing to the phenotype, and the high degree of consanguinity between the proband's parents.

Functional data should not be taken into account, as the authors showed that a simliar but non-identical truncated PROM1 protein expressed in CHO cells is unstable and does not reach the cell surface.

evidence.rdfs:label: Zhang_2014_Family_E_Proband_II:1
evidence.detectionMethod: Genotyping was performed by capture next-generation sequencing of the ABCA4, PROM1, PRPH2, VMD2 and ELOVL4 genes, followed by Sanger sequencing of certain exons, and segregation analysis within the family members.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The patient was diagnosed with Stargardt disease initially, and subsequently with cone-rod dystrophy. Features included Macular atrophy, Color vision defect, Abnormal best corrected visual acuity test, Decreased Arden ratio of electrooculogram, Attenuation of retinal blood vessels, Macular atrophy, Decreased light- and dark-adapted electroretinogram amplitude, Photoreceptor layer loss on macular OCT, Retinal pigment epithelial atrophy, and Central scotoma.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Previous testing consisted of Capture Next Generation Sequencing of the ABCA4, PROM1, PRPH2, VMD2 and ELOVL4 genes.

evidence.dc:description: Default scoring has been recommended, as the NM_006017.3(PROM1):c.730C>T (p.Arg244Ter) variant introduces a premature stop codon into exon 8 of 28 and is predicted to trigger nonsense-mediated decay.
The variant has been moderately down-scored for lack of confirmation of its effect on the protein product.
